items.title: Morrison's plan to reform Islamic teaching 'worth looking at', Liberal says
items.description: Liberal frontbencher Andrew Bragg says Australian Muslims need to take some responsibility for extremist incidents and that a proposal for a register of Islamic preachers is worth considering.

items.title: Live: Świątek, Djokovic and Sinner in action in Australian Open quarters
items.description: Iga Świątek, Novak Djokovic and Jannik Sinner are among the big names in action on day 11 at the Australian Open as we fast approach the business end of the tournament. Follow the action in our live blog.

items.title: TikTok settles as social media giants face trial over youth addiction claims
items.description: TikTok agrees to settle a landmark lawsuit on social media addiction, the same day the trial was due to start against Meta and YouTube.

items.title: Ukraine-Russia war casualties near 2 million, CSIS study finds

featured_image.name: Troop Casualties in Ukraine War Near 2 Million, Study Finds

items.description:
Nearly four years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the combined military toll of the conflict is approaching two million casualties, according to a study released Tuesday by the Center for Strategic and International Studies.

The Washington-based think tank estimates approximately 1.2 million Russian troops and close to 600,000 Ukrainian soldiers have been killed, wounded, or gone missing since February 2022, bringing the current total to roughly 1.8 million. By this spring, the study projects, that figure will reach two million if current trends continue.[1][2]

items.title: Colombia's Petro says Maduro should face trial in Venezuela

featured_image.name: Petro Says Maduro Should be Returned to Face Trial in ...

items.description:
Colombian President Gustavo Petro said Tuesday that ousted Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro should be returned to face trial in his home country rather than in the United States, adding a new layer of complexity to regional tensions one week before his scheduled meeting with President Donald Trump.

"They have to return him and have him tried by a Venezuelan court, not a US one," Petro said Tuesday, according to Bloomberg. The statement marks the Colombian leader's most direct intervention yet in the diplomatic standoff over Maduro's fate since US forces captured the former Venezuelan president in a dramatic pre-dawn raid on January 3.[1]

items.title: Live: Inflation rises to 3.8pc increasing likelihood of interest rate hike
items.description: The Consumer Price Index rose by 3.8 per cent in the 12 months to December 2025, according to the latest data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS), ahead of next week's first Reserve Bank meeting of 2026. Follow live.

items.title: 'Patience is at an end': Minnesota judge orders ICE head to face court
items.description: A Minnesota judge takes the extraordinary step of ordering the acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) to appear in person and explain why his agency keeps ignoring court orders.

items.title: NASA's Juno measures Europa's ice shell at 18 miles thick

featured_image.name: NASA's Juno probe will peer beneath the icy crust of Europa ...

items.description:
Jupiter's moon Europa remains one of the most tantalizing targets in the search for extraterrestrial life, but two recent studies paint a complex and sometimes contradictory picture of whether its vast subsurface ocean could actually support living organisms.

NASA announced on Sunday that data from the Juno spacecraft has provided the first direct measurement of Europa's ice shell thickness, determining it averages about 18 miles (29 kilometers) in the region observed during a 2022 flyby. The findings, published in Nature Astronomy in December, represent a landmark measurement that settles a long-standing scientific debate over whether the shell is thin or thick.[1][2][3]

"The 18-mile estimate relates to the cold, rigid, conductive outer-layer of a pure water ice shell," said Steve Levin, Juno project scientist at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. "If an inner, slightly warmer convective layer also exists, which is possible, the total ice shell thickness would be even greater."[2][3]

items.title: Tesla brand value drops 36% as Musk's politics erode trust

featured_image.name: Tesla investor survey shows 85% believe Musk's politics are ...

items.description:
Tesla faces a crossroads this week as its brand value hits a three-year low and Wall Street braces for another year of declining profitability. The electric vehicle maker is scheduled to report fourth-quarter 2025 earnings on Wednesday, January 28, amid mounting evidence that CEO Elon Musk's political activities and the company's aging vehicle lineup are weighing heavily on business performance.

According to Brand Finance, Tesla's brand value fell by $15.4 billion, or 36%, in 2025, marking its third consecutive annual decline. The London-based research firm now values the Tesla brand at $27.61 billion, down from $43 billion at the start of 2025 and well below its peak of $66.2 billion in January 2023.[1][2][3]

items.title: Live: Colin Boyce to move Nationals spill motion and run for leader
items.description: Nationals MP Colin Boyce has flagged his plans to challenge David Littleproud for leadership of the party when parliament returns next week. Follow live.

items.title: Live: NSW towns bake in 'breathtaking' heat
items.description: Towns in New South Wales and Queensland are sweltering today amid a record-breaking heatwave, as firefighters continue to battle multiple blazes in Victoria. Follow live.

items.title: Australia's largest city is running out of landfill. It's causing a trash war
items.description: A proposal to build an incinerator in the regional town of Parkes could see 700,000 tonnes of Sydney's red bin rubbish transported there every year.

items.title: Government turns defence sights north with $355m RAAF base upgrade
items.description: A Royal Australian Air Force base near Katherine in the NT is updated with purpose-built hangars and improved runways.

items.title: Rally organiser's claim of 'bashing' by Middle Eastern men comes unstuck
items.description: March for Australia claims one of its organisers was bashed by a group of Middle Eastern men the day before Australia Day, but police and an eyewitness account have cast doubt on its claim.

items.title: Study finds narrow ocean bands absorb 72% of seas' carbon

featured_image.name: Ocean fronts revealed as key players in Earth's carbon cycle

items.description:
Narrow bands of ocean covering just over one-third of the world's seas are responsible for absorbing nearly three-quarters of the carbon dioxide that oceans pull from the atmosphere, according to new research that reshapes scientific understanding of Earth's carbon cycle.

The study, published in Nature Climate Change, reveals that ocean fronts—turbulent boundaries where different water masses collide—cover 36 percent of the global ocean but account for 72 percent of total oceanic carbon dioxide uptake, absorbing approximately 1.8 billion tons of carbon annually.[1][2][3]

"This is the first time we've been able to quantify the disproportionate role that ocean fronts play in absorbing atmospheric CO2 on a global scale, and it has major implications for climate modelling," said lead author Dr. Kai Yang, who completed the research during his PhD at the University of Tasmania's Institute for Marine and Antarctic Studies (IMAS) and is now a postdoctoral researcher at Xiamen University in China.[4][1]

items.title: OpenAI releases free AI workspace for scientists
items.description:
OpenAI released Prism on Tuesday, a free AI-powered research and writing workspace designed to accelerate scientific work. The platform integrates GPT-5.2 and is available to anyone with a ChatGPT account, marking the company's first dedicated tool for the scientific community.[1][2][3]

"In 2025, AI changed software development forever," OpenAI said in its announcement. "In 2026, we expect a comparable shift in science."[4]

items.title: Lunai Bioworks launches AI tool to block chemical weapon design

featured_image.name: Without safeguards, AI-Biology integration risks accelerating future ...

items.description:
Lunai Bioworks on Tuesday announced the deployment of Sentinel, a transformer-based AI safeguard designed to prevent large language models and scientific AI systems from generating novel chemical agents. The Sacramento-based biotech company said the technology embeds directly within foundation models to screen molecular outputs in real time, functioning as what CEO David Weinstein described as "the immune system for scientific AI."[1][2]

"As AI models become more powerful, safety has to move closer to the core," Weinstein said in a statement. "Sentinel operates inside AI systems—not outside them—stopping dangerous chemical designs before they are ever produced."[3][1]

The launch comes amid mounting concern over the dual-use risks of advanced AI in chemistry and biology, with major AI companies including Anthropic and OpenAI warning that powerful models could assist bad actors in developing biological and chemical threats.

items.title: OpenAI launches dedicated team to accelerate AI use in science

featured_image.name: Altman touts trillion-dollar AI vision as OpenAI ...

items.description:
OpenAI has unveiled a dedicated team to transform the use of artificial intelligence in scientific research, positioning its GPT-5 model as a collaborative partner for mathematicians and scientists while urging policymakers to expand support for AI-driven discovery.

The initiative, called OpenAI for Science, was first announced in October 2025 and is led by Kevin Weil, a company vice president with a background in particle physics who nearly completed a PhD at Stanford before entering the tech industry.[1][2]

items.title: Chinese firm unveils plan to send humanoid robot to space

featured_image.name: Chinese firm launches effort to send humanoid robot into ...

items.description: A Chinese humanoid robot has been directly connected to a low-Earth orbit satellite for the first time in the world, while a separate initiative aims to send a humanoid into space as a robot astronaut—two advances that underscore China's accelerating push into the burgeoning field of embodied artificial intelligence.

items.title: Carney rejects US claim he walked back criticism of Trump trade policy

featured_image.name: Carney walked back Davos comments in call with Trump, US treasury chief says

items.description:
Prime Minister Mark Carney told President Donald Trump that Canada stands by its trade diversification strategy and recent deal with China during a phone call Monday, pushing back against claims from the Trump administration that he had backed down from his earlier criticism of American trade policy.

"I meant what I said in Davos," Carney told reporters Tuesday before a cabinet meeting in Ottawa. "Canada was the first country to understand the change in U.S. trade policy that he had initiated, and we're responding to that."[1][2]

The call comes amid escalating tensions between Washington and Ottawa as the two countries prepare for a formal review of the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement later this year. Trump had threatened over the weekend to impose 100% tariffs on Canadian goods if Canada proceeds with a trade agreement with China, posting on Truth Social that Prime Minister Carney was "gravely mistaken" if he thought Canada could become a "Drop Off Port" for Chinese products.[3][4]

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
